creator: FHDM Apps
descriptionHtml:
Combine Scoppy with a Raspberry Pi Pico development board to create an affordable low frequency Oscilloscope.

Key Features:
- Horizontal scale and position adjustments
- Vertical scale and position adjustments
- Trigger channel and level selection
- Two Channels (second channel requires premium upgrade)
- Up to 500k samples per second (shared between channels)

Demo Mode
You can use the demo mode to explore some of the capabilities of the app without having to connect to a Pico. To enable demo mode tap the USB badge at the bottom left of the screen. Then tap 'Change input' and select Demo.

More information
Instructions for installing the firmware and attaching the Pico can be found here: https://github.com/fhdm-dev/scoppy
descriptionShort: Oscilloscope powered by RP Pico frontend

appDetails.recentChangesHtml: Initial Release

appDetails.recentChangesHtml: Added trigger level buttons to control menu

title: Scoppy - Oscilloscope

creator: FHDM Apps
descriptionHtml:
Combine Scoppy with a Raspberry Pi Pico to create an oscilloscope for measuring signals up to 50kHz.

Key Features:
- Horizontal scale and position adjustments
- Vertical scale and position adjustments
- Trigger channel and level selection
- Two Channels (second channel requires premium upgrade)
- Up to 500k samples per second (shared between channels)
- Memory depth up to 20kpts
- Time/Div: 5us - 20secs

More information
More information including instructions for installing the (free) firmware onto your Pico can be found here: https://github.com/fhdm-dev/scoppy
descriptionShort: Oscilloscope powered by a Raspberry Pi Pico

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
Added Normal triggering
Added Single-shot capture
Easier adjustment of trigger level and channel
Support for multiple voltage ranges per channel

title: Scoppy - Oscilloscope

creator: FHDM Apps
descriptionHtml:
Combine Scoppy with a Raspberry Pi Pico to create a 500kS/s oscilloscope and 20MS/s logic analyzer.

Key Features:
- Horizontal scale and position adjustments
- Vertical scale and position adjustments
- Trigger channel and level selection
- Auto and Normal triggering
- Memory depth up to 100kpts for single captures

Oscilloscope
- Two Channels
- Up to 500k samples per second (shared between channels)
- Time/Div: 5us - 20secs

Logic Analyzer
- Eight Channels
- Up to 20M samples per second (per channel)
- Time/Div: 50ns - 100ms

More information
More information including instructions for installing the (free) firmware onto your Pico can be found here: https://github.com/fhdm-dev/scoppy
descriptionShort: Oscilloscope and Logic Analyzer powered by a Raspberry Pi Pico

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
* Logic analyzer mode
* 'Keep screen on' setting

* Improved logic analyzer triggering at higher sample rates
! Please ensure you are running the latest version of the scoppy-pico firmware (v6)

title: Scoppy - Oscilloscope and Logic Analyzer

creator: FHDM Apps
descriptionHtml:
Combine Scoppy with a Raspberry Pi Pico to create a 500kS/s oscilloscope and 25MS/s logic analyzer.

Key Features:
- Horizontal scale and position adjustments
- Vertical scale and position adjustments
- Trigger channel and level selection
- Rising edge and falling edge triggers
- Auto and Normal triggering
- Continuous (Run) and Single capture modes
- Memory depth up to 100kpts for single captures
- Vertical and Horizontal Cursors
- Auto or fixed sample rate
- % pre-trigger samples setting
- Signal Generator
--- square wave (100Hz - 1.25MHz)
--- 1kHz PWM sine wave

Oscilloscope
- Two Channels
- Up to 500k samples per second (shared between channels)
- Time/Div: 5us - 20secs
- Up to 4 configurable voltage ranges per channel (see help for details)

Logic Analyzer
- Eight Channels
- Up to 25M samples per second (per channel)
- Time/Div: 50ns - 100ms

Analog Front End
Connect the input signal directly to the Pico ADC pins for 0-3.3V inputs or build your own analog front end. Several cheap and easy to build open-source designs can be found at oscilloscope.fhdm.xyz

More information
More information including instructions for installing the (free and open-source) firmware onto your Pico can be found here: https://github.com/fhdm-dev/scoppy and https://oscilloscope.fhdm.xyz
descriptionShort: Oscilloscope and Logic Analyzer powered by a Raspberry Pi Pico

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
* On-screen measurements can now be hidden and/or configured
* More measurements are available via the new Measurement Snapshot window
* Captured samples can be exported to a CSV file
* More sane behavior when multiple USB devices are attached via a hub
* Tap-and-hold a channel badge to enable/disable the channel

title: Scoppy - Oscilloscope and Logic Analyzer

creator: FHDM Apps
descriptionHtml:
Combine Scoppy with a Raspberry Pi Pico to create a 500kS/s oscilloscope and 25MS/s logic analyzer.

Key Features:
- Horizontal scale and position adjustments
- Vertical scale and position adjustments
- Trigger channel and level selection
- Rising edge and falling edge triggers
- Auto and Normal triggering
- Continuous (Run) and Single capture modes
- Memory depth up to 100kpts for single captures
- Vertical and Horizontal Cursors
- Auto or fixed sample rate
- % pre-trigger samples setting
- Signal Generator
--- square wave (100Hz - 1.25MHz)
--- 1kHz PWM sine wave
- X-Y Mode
- FFT
--- Hann, Hamming, Blackman and Rectangle windows
--- vertical and horizontal cursors
--- dBm, dBmV and V vertical units
--- option to display both channels simultaneously
--- option to display the scope window alongside the FFT
- Probe attenuation settings eg. 1X, 10X, custom

Oscilloscope
- Two Channels
- Up to 500k samples per second (shared between channels)
- Time/Div: 5us - 20secs
- Up to 4 configurable voltage ranges per channel (see help for details)

Logic Analyzer
- Eight Channels
- Up to 25M samples per second (per channel)
- Time/Div: 50ns - 100ms

Analog Front End
Connect the input signal directly to the Pico ADC pins for 0-3.3V inputs or build your own analog front end. Several cheap and easy to build open-source designs can be found at oscilloscope.fhdm.xyz

More information
More information including instructions for installing the (free and open-source) firmware onto your Pico can be found here: https://github.com/fhdm-dev/scoppy and https://oscilloscope.fhdm.xyz
descriptionShort: Oscilloscope and Logic Analyzer powered by your Raspberry Pi Pico

appDetails.recentChangesHtml: FFT and X-Y mode improvements

WiFi support

title: Scoppy - Oscilloscope

creator: FHDM TECH
descriptionHtml:
Combine the Scoppy app with a Raspberry Pi Pico or Pico W to create a 500kS/s oscilloscope and 25MS/s logic analyzer.

Key Features:
- Wireless connectivity with the Pico W
- Horizontal scale and position adjustments
- Vertical scale and position adjustments
- Trigger channel and level selection
- Rising edge and falling edge triggers
- Auto and Normal triggering
- Continuous (Run) and Single capture modes
- Memory depth up to 100kpts for single captures
- Vertical and Horizontal Cursors
- Auto or fixed sample rate
- % pre-trigger samples setting
- Signal Generator
--- square wave (100Hz - 1.25MHz)
--- 1kHz PWM sine wave
- X-Y Mode
- FFT
--- Hann, Hamming, Blackman and Rectangle windows
--- vertical and horizontal cursors
--- dBm, dBmV and V vertical units
--- option to display both channels simultaneously
--- option to display the scope window alongside the FFT
- Probe attenuation settings eg. 1X, 10X, custom

Oscilloscope
- Two Channels
- Up to 500k samples per second (shared between channels)
- Time/Div: 5us - 20secs
- Up to 4 configurable voltage ranges per channel (see help for details)

Logic Analyzer
- Eight Channels
- Up to 25M samples per second (per channel)
- Time/Div: 50ns - 100ms

Analog Front End
Connect the input signal directly to the Pico ADC pins for a 0-3.3V input range or build your own analog front end to extend the input range. Several cheap and easy to build open-source designs can be found at oscilloscope.fhdm.xyz. Affordable front ends are also available for purchase at store.fhdm.xyz.

More information
More information including instructions for installing the free firmware onto your Pico or Pico W can be found here: https://github.com/fhdm-dev/scoppy and https://oscilloscope.fhdm.xyz
descriptionShort: Oscilloscope and Logic Analyzer powered by your Raspberry Pi Pico

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
Allow connection to Pico W via Wi-Fi
Change trigger level by dragging indicator
Option to not overwrite voltage range settings
Improved stability

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
Sin(x)/x interpolation
Firmware GPIO mappings can now be configured from the app
Firmware channel settings can now be configured from the app
Maximum number of voltage ranges per channel increased to 8
Support for analog front-ends with inverting configuration

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
* A 'Reset Connection' option has now been added to the connection menu (tap the connection badge at the lower left of the screen). Use this if the app is taking too long to connect to the Oscilloscope.
* When configuring the firmware Wi-Fi settings, the AP name (SSID) can now be selected from a list (rather than having to be typed in manually). Android will ask for location permission settings when this feature is used for the first time.
* Reduced min Time/Div to 1us

- % pre-trigger samples setting
- Signal Generator
--- square wave (100Hz - 1.25MHz)
--- 1kHz PWM sine wave
- X-Y Mode
- FFT
--- Hann, Hamming, Blackman and Rectangle windows
--- vertical and horizontal cursors
--- dBm, dBmV and V vertical units
--- option to display both channels simultaneously
--- option to display the scope window alongside the FFT
- Probe attenuation settings eg. 1X, 10X, custom

Oscilloscope
- Two Channels
- Up to 500k samples per second (shared between channels)
- Time/Div: 5us - 20secs
- Up to 4 configurable voltage ranges per channel (see help for details)

Logic Analyzer
- Eight Channels
- Up to 25M samples per second (per channel)
- Time/Div: 50ns - 100ms

Analog Front End
Connect the input signal directly to the Pico ADC pins for a 0-3.3V input range or build your own analog front end to extend the input range. Several cheap and easy to build open-source designs can be found at oscilloscope.fhdm.xyz. Affordable front ends are also available for purchase at store.fhdm.xyz.

More information
More information including instructions for installing the free firmware onto your Pico or Pico W can be found here: https://github.com/fhdm-dev/scoppy and https://oscilloscope.fhdm.xyz
descriptionShort: Oscilloscope and Logic Analyzer powered by your Raspberry Pi Pico

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
* Tapping the ROLL button will enter (and leave) roll mode.
* Record length can now be set to a fixed value (tap the displayed record length at the top of the screen)
* Added support for the FHDM DSO500K-U oscilloscope

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
* App can be displayed in both landscape orientations
* Probe attenuation is saved to settings
* Roll mode is now automatic
* Single shot now always waits for a trigger
* Can connect to device via hotspot network

appDetails.recentChangesHtml:
* Minor fix to the display of the current sample rate and record length
* Better feedback during single shot captures at very slow sample rates
* A setting to quadruple the max. sample rate of the RP2040 to 2MS/s. This requires firmware version 17 or higher.
